Technical Assistance Report 
 
 
Project Number: 44367-012 
Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (PATA) 
December 2010 
 
 
 
 
India: Knowledge Management for Inclusive Growth 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 10 November 2010)

Re1.00 =  $0.02250 
$1.00 =  Rs44.2650 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DEA  –  Department of Economic Affairs 
  MOU  –  memorandum of understanding 
  PPP  –  public–private partnership 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Policy and advisory technical assistance (PATA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Multisector 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Sustainable  economic  growth  (widening  access  to  markets  and 
economic  opportunities,  promoting  economic  efficiency  and 
enabling  business  environment,  promoting  macro-economic 
stability); governance (economic and financial governance) 
Location impact  –  National (high), rural (medium), urban (medium), regional (low) 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice-President  X. Zhao, Operations 1 
Director General  S. H. Rahman, South Asia Department (SARD) 
Country Director  H. Kim, India Resident Mission (INRM), SARD 
   
Team leader  R. Hasan, Principal Economist, INRM, SARD 
Team member  K. Iyengar, Economics Officer, INRM, SARD 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of India has asked that the Asian Development Bank (ADB) continue 
providing policy advisory technical assistance (TA) for knowledge management activities.  This 
request follows two previous knowledge management TA projects that met the government’s 
expectations  regarding  ADB’s  role  as  a  knowledge  provider  by  supporting  analytical 
assessments in critical areas of development and reform, documentation, and dissemination.1 
While the earlier TA included capacity building, the government has asked that this TA focus on 
knowledge management activities in knowledge creation, dissemination, and partnerships. The 
TA will aim to provide advisory inputs for government policy and projects related to achieving 
inclusive growth, especially in areas relevant to ADB’s India program.  ADB and the government 
have reached agreement on the impact, outcome, implementation arrangements, and cost and 
financing arrangements of the TA.2 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.   
 
2.  The knowledge management activities of this TA align with ADB’s commitment to being 
a primary source of development knowledge in the Asia and Pacific region. This commitment 
aims to improve the quality of ADB operations and enhance the capacity of developing member 
countries.  ADB’s Strategy 2020 identifies help for developing countries to gain knowledge as an 
important driver of change.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The  TA  is  designed  to  use  knowledge  management  activities  to  support  the 
government’s efforts at promoting inclusive growth. Under the government’s Eleventh Five-Year 
Plan (April 2007–March 2012), inclusive growth involves a broad-based improvement in living 
standards and requires not only that economic growth be high and sustainable but that it also be 
dispersed by region and sector and both generate and be driven by good quality employment 
for the workforce at large. 
 
4.  In its pursuit of inclusive growth, the government has put a priority on tackling India’s 
infrastructure deficit, spurring growth in lagging states, reinvigorating the rural economy, and 
enabling manufacturing and services to generate good jobs on a large scale. These efforts to 
expand economic opportunities are being complemented by a critically important stepping-up of 
investments  in  education  and  health  and  a  host  of  targeted  social  and  livelihood-related 
programs for the poor. The government also recognizes the need to ensure that growth is 
environmentally sustainable. 
 
5.  The TA will seek to help answer many questions about the effectiveness of these efforts, 
with a view to using the knowledge to improve future policy and planning for inclusive growth 
and ADB’s own operations including support for ADB’s knowledge management action plan.4 
These questions are particularly important at this juncture, given the government's ambitious 
inclusive growth program and its recent willingness to use innovative mechanisms to finance 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance to India for Knowledge Management and Capacity Building. Manila (TA 4780-
IND, for $2,000,000, approved on 17 April); ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance to India for Knowledge Management 
for Enhanced Operational Effectiveness. Manila (TA 7092-IND, $1,000,000, approved on 27 June, closing on 30 
June 2011). 
2  The TA was not included in the country operations business plan 2011–2013 but has been included in the 2010 
country program, based on discussions with the government. The TA first appeared in the business opportunities 
section of ADB’s website on 23 November 2010.  
3  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila.  
4 ADB.2009. Enhancing Knowledge Management Under Strategy 2020: Plan of Action for 2009-2011. Manila

2 
and manage initiatives under this agenda.  For example, investment in agriculture—for too long 
a  lagging  sector  in  India—has  increased  in  a  significant  way,  while  the  Prime  Minister’s 
Grameen Sadak Yojana (a central government program for building all-weather roads in rural 
areas), which has been supported by ADB, has improved rural road connectivity.  What is the 
impact  of  these  interventions  on  development  outcomes?    Are  there  complementary 
interventions that can raise their effectiveness—for example, improving access to finance for 
rural entrepreneurs and providing skills development programs? The government is also relying 
on or considering the use of public–private partnerships (PPPs) to alleviate both financial and 
managerial  constraints  across  a  broad  range  of  sectors,  including  transport  and  energy 
infrastructure and education and skills development. What are the emerging lessons from the 
use of PPPs in different sectors and contexts? 
 
6.  Answering questions such as these is also crucially important to ADB's India operations. 
ADB's India country partnership strategy, 2009–2012 and the draft country operations business 
plan, 2011–2013 have been designed to support the government’s efforts at promoting inclusive 
growth.5 Prior to 2003, ADB had operations in states that are relatively better-off, such as 
Gujarat, Karnataka, and Kerala. ADB assistance has since been extended to states such as 
Assam, Bihar, Chhattisgarh, Jharkand, Madhya Pradesh, Orissa, and Rajasthan that suffer from 
one or more of the following problems: high poverty incidence, low levels of social development, 
weak capacity, and poor infrastructure.  In addition, the recent expansion of operations into new 
sectors such as agribusiness, water resources management, and support for the development 
of rural cooperatives and micro, small, and medium enterprises will make ADB’s support for the 
government’s inclusive growth agenda more direct. Knowledge management activities, including 
knowledge creation, dissemination, and partnerships, will be critical for ensuring that these and 
future efforts are highly effective.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The expected impact of the TA will be to raise the development effectiveness of policy 
and project interventions in sectors that are identified by the government as crucial for achieving 
inclusive growth and are of operational relevance to ADB.  The TA aims to do this through its 
expected outcome—improved understanding of the types of policy and project interventions that 
are  effective  in  promoting  inclusive  growth  and  the  dissemination  of  the  TA  outputs  that 
contribute to this improved understanding. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will generate and disseminate evidence on the types of policy and project 
interventions that are effective in promoting inclusive growth through three types of activities: 
 
1.  Knowledge Creation 
 
9.  The TA will support studies aimed at promoting a better understanding of the impact and 
effectiveness of different types of policies and projects.  The studies will focus on sectors and 
issues that are identified by the government as crucial for achieving inclusive growth and are of 
operational relevance to ADB.  While there will be flexibility on the types of studies carried out, 
the  three  main  categories  include  in-depth  studies  on  selected  sector  or  thematic  issues, 
                                                 
5  ADB. 2009. Country Partnership Strategy: India, 2009–2012. Manila.

3
scoping  studies  that  conduct  an  initial  analysis  on  a  given  topic  or  issue,  and  shorter 
development briefs.6 
 
10.  While  development  briefs  will  focus  on  distilling  lessons  from  ADB  operations  on 
operational effectiveness and development outcomes, and include assessments of operational 
risk as necessary, the topics and scope of the other two types of studies will be broader. 
Prospective topics include options for promoting financial inclusion; understanding the nature of 
skill deficits and modalities for reducing these; raising agricultural productivity and improving 
rural livelihoods through, for example, water and natural resource management; determining 
efficient and feasible approaches for providing low-cost housing in urban areas; fostering the 
development of small and medium-sized enterprises; and the efficacy of PPPs in areas such as 
rural health and education services.   
 
11.  Some studies are expected to focus on documenting how key development outcomes 
have  evolved  over  time  and  across  India  and  selected  states  and  on  understanding  the 
channels that influence the evolution of these development outcomes.7  Some studies may also 
focus on macroeconomic issues that set the context in which ADB's India program operates and 
directly impinge on selected ADB operations, such as ADB's involvement in fiscal reforms in 
select Indian states.  Macroeconomic issues also often have direct effects on the government's 
ability  to  make  growth  more  inclusive.  Regional  cooperation  and  environment  and  climate 
change issues will be incorporated, as required and feasible. 
 
12.  The methodologies to be used by the studies will be driven by their scope. Thus, studies 
are expected to be based variously on desk reviews, field visits, comparative analyses, and the 
analysis of survey and administrative data, among other approaches.  Both qualitative analysis 
(for  example,  case  studies  using  key  informant  interviews)  and  quantitative  analysis  (for 
example, analysis of survey data using statistical and econometric tools) will be employed, 
depending on need and feasibility. Both pre- and post-policy or project impact assessment 
methods will be considered.  High standards of rigor will be maintained in all cases.  
 
13.  The  specific  topics  and  issues  that  will  be  studied  will  be  determined  through 
consultations with the government, ADB sector specialists, and external experts. An advisory 
committee (detailed in para. 22) will make the final decision on which studies will be carried out 
under the TA. The studies will be undertaken in-house; through national and/or international 
consultants; by accredited institutions or firms; and/or in partnership with research institutions 
through memorandums of understanding (MOUs) under guidance of the advisory committee. 
 
2.  Knowledge Dissemination 
 
14.  Conferences,  seminars,  workshops,  and  other  knowledge-sharing  activities. 
Besides  events  to  disseminate  study  findings  among  stakeholders,  the  TA  will  support 
conferences,  seminars,  and  workshop  events  on  a  focused  basis.  These  will  be  in  areas 
relevant to ADB operations in India. Resource persons will collate outcomes and synthesize 
highlights of learning events for broader dissemination, when necessary.  
                                                 
6  Scoping studies typically involve a brief survey of the state of knowledge on a given topic or issue. They identify

resources and time permit. 
7  One such study is expected to be methodological in nature and review existing benefit monitoring and evaluation 
arrangements  under  selected  ADB-assisted  projects  and  consider  the  possibility  of  institutionalizing  data 
management arrangements for benefit monitoring and evaluation arrangements.

4 
 
15.  Publications. Studies carried out under the TA and by ADB, conference outcomes, 
good  practices,  and  other  material  that  will  enhance  value  added  and  awareness  through 
knowledge dissemination will be considered for publication. The publications will be in line with 
ADB goals and cleared by the Department of External Relations in accordance with ADB 
procedures. 
 
16.  Internal knowledge enhancement through cross-learning. To encourage creation 
and sharing of knowledge and experiences, knowledge enhancement events will be supported 
for staff on development effectiveness issues. 
 
17.  Visits to best-practices sites (national, regional, or international) for learning by 
seeing. The TA will support hands-on learning through visits to sites of successful initiatives by 
government officials who are directly concerned with project design and implementation. Sector 
specialists or mission leaders of the various ongoing and proposed ADB-supported projects will 
prepare requests for such site visits. Participating officials from executing agencies will be 
required to prepare and provide a two-page report on how they propose to operationalize the 
lessons from the study tours and will conduct a dissemination seminar for other members in the 
executing agencies and sector departments.  
 
18.  Web-based  electronic  facility.  The  TA  will  support  the  creation  of  a  web-based 
electronic facility and the use of information technology for knowledge sharing. This will include 
hardware  and  software  components  (i.e.,  enablers  such  as  document  repositories,  portal 
development, and online conference tools).  
 
  3.  Knowledge Partnerships and Networking 
 
19.  The TA will also support partnerships and networking activities through MOUs between 
ADB and such knowledge partners as senior policymakers, public nonprofit research institutions 
of  national  importance,  civil  society  stakeholders,  individual  experts,  and  opinion  makers. 
Support  to  and  collaboration  with  academic  and  research  institutions,  think  tanks,  and 
development partners will be undertaken on identified issues.  MOUs will be signed for studies 
that will forge linkages and develop networks for dialogue and to disseminate findings. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
20.  The estimated cost of the TA is equivalent to $1,875,000, of which, the equivalent of 
$1,500,000 will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund 
(TASF-other sources). The government will finance the equivalent of $375,000 in kind.  The cost 
estimates and financing plan is in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  The  Department  of  Economic  Affairs  (DEA)  of  the  Ministry  of  Finance  will  be  the 
executing agency for the TA.  The DEA will partner closely with ADB’s India Resident Mission in 
implementing  the  TA.    In  addition  to  providing  counterpart  staff  and  assisting  with 
documentation  requirements,  the  DEA  will  consult  with  government  agencies  on  their 
knowledge management needs.  The resident mission will coordinate overall implementation of 
the TA.

5
22.  The TA will be guided by an advisory committee co-chaired by the country director of the 
India  Resident  Mission  and  the  joint  secretary  (multilateral  institutions)  of  the  DEA.  The 
committee will comprise the ADB project officer and sector specialists at the resident mission.  
Inputs from sector directors of ADB South Asia Department and representatives from ADB 
Regional  and  Sustainable  Development  Department  and  ADB  Economics  Research 
Department will be sought, when appropriate. The advisory committee will meet as needed to 
monitor progress of TA activities. 
 
23.  The  TA  approval  mechanism  is  designed  to  ensure  timely  response  to  operational 
requirements. For proposals involving major knowledge creation activities, such as in-depth 
studies, the advisory committee will be responsible for endorsement and approval. The country 
director, India Resident Mission will be responsible for endorsement and approval of (i) minor 
knowledge-creation  activities  involving  scoping  studies  and  low-cost  desk  studies;  (ii) 
knowledge  dissemination  activities  such  as  workshops,  seminars,  and  conferences;  (iii) 
meetings and retreats; and (iv) learning events. Feedback from peer reviewers and national and 
international experts will be sought to evaluate studies and ensure quality.  Subcommittees of 
policymakers and experts may be constituted for some of the more detailed in-depth studies.  
 
24.  The TA will require about 154 person-months of consulting services, consisting of 10 
person-months of international inputs, 96 person-months of national inputs, and 48 person-
months of survey and associated study inputs by a firm.  It will be implemented over a 3-year 
period (36 months), with an additional 3 months for TA closing. International and national 
individual consultants will be selected and engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). In addition, the TA will also 
finance a survey-based study by a firm or institution engaged through consultants’ qualification 
selection  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants.  The  choice  of 
consultants’ qualification selection stems from the relatively small budget for the survey work 
($100,000) and the straightforward but specialized nature of the work. Disbursements under the 
TA will be made in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, 
as amended from time to time). 
 
25.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  over  a  3-year  period,  from  15  December  2010  to  14 
December 2013. TA outputs will be disseminated thorough publication of discussion papers, 
books, reports, conference and seminar briefings, etc., and will also be posted on the intranet.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
26.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of India for Knowledge Management for Inclusive Growth, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

Appendix 3      9 
 
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The consultants will be individual consultants, selected and engaged in accordance with 
the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of 
consultants. A consultant firm may be hired to conduct a survey and accompanying study if it is 
required by the technical assistance (TA). The terms of reference for up to 10 international and 
96 national consultant person-months are outlined below.  Also outlined below are the terms of 
reference for 48 person-months for consultant firms for survey work. 
 
A.  Economic Analysts: Long-Term National Individual Consultants (72 person-months) 
 
2.  The consultants will 
 
(i)  prepare short papers on topics identified during TA implementation; 
(ii)  assist ADB staff in data collection, analysis, and writing on topics identified during 
TA implementation; 
(iii)  develop and implement a management information system for the TA; 
(iv)  assist in preparation for workshops, seminars, and conferences; and 
(v)  participate in TA missions, as required. 
 
B.  Economists: Short-Term National Individual Consultants (24 person-months) 
 
3.  The consultants will 
 
(i)  provide specialized inputs on selected sectors, states, and crosscutting themes; 
and 
(ii)  prepare  studies  to  be identified  during  project  implementation,  with terms  of 
reference developed as the studies are identified. 
 
C.  Economists: International Individual Consultants (10 person-months) 
 
4.  International consultants will be hired on a needs basis. They will 
 
(i)  review papers and provide advisory inputs as part of subcommittees or as peer 
reviewers; 
(ii)  ensure international best-practice policies are taken into account in the studies; 
and 
(iii)  participate at workshops and seminars, as required, and provide inputs to 
evaluate the TA before completion. 
 
D.  Consultant Firm: Survey-based Study (48 person-months) 
 
5.  A firm may be recruited to undertake an in-depth survey-based study and for preparation 
of survey instruments, including sampling design, field operations, and data processing. The 
survey  will  cover  households  and/or  enterprises,  as  appropriate.  The  firm  will perform  the 
following activities, as defined by ADB staff: 
   
(i)  Develop the methodology and detailed outline for the identified study

10  Appendix 3 
 
(ii)  Prepare a literature survey for the study, design appropriate questionnaire to 
cover all the survey objectives, prepare supervisors’ and enumerators manuals 
and training materials for enumerators.   
(iii)  Develop  an  appropriate,  workable  structure  for  the  survey,  given  a  specific 
budget and target population. 
(iv)  Undertake survey operations within an agreed time period 
(v)  Ensure  that  the  sampling  design  is  accurately  implemented  and  that 
measurement errors are minimized in the survey process 
(vi)  Validate and process the survey data and deliver the validated survey data by 
the date agreed 
(viii)  Perform a complete analysis of the data and prepare the study report
